section.p: The SYSCS_DIAG.TRANSACTION_TABLE diagnostic table shows all of the transactions that are currently in the database. You can reference the SYSCS_DIAG.TRANSACTION_TABLE diagnostic table directly in a statement.

When the SYSCS_DIAG.TRANSACTION_TABLE diagnostic table is referenced in a statement, a snapshot of the transaction table is taken. A snapshot is used so that referencing the diagnostic table does not alter the normal timing and flow of the application. It is possible that some transactions will be in a transition state when the snapshot is taken.
For a database for which authentication and SQL authorization are both enabled, only the database owner can access this diagnostic table.
The table has the columns shown in the following table.

table.title: Columns in the SYSCS_DIAG.TRANSACTION_TABLE table
table.desc: For the columns in the SYSCS_DIAG.TRANSACTION_TABLE table, this table provides its data type, its length in bytes, whether it is nullable, and a description of its contents.

row.entry: The transaction id, which can be joined with the lock table virtual table's XID. See .
The global transaction ID, set only if this transaction is a participant in a distributed transaction.
The user name (the default value is APP). May appear null if the transaction is started by .
Either 'UserTransaction' or an internal transaction spawned by .

Either 'IDLE' or 'ACTIVE'. A transaction is IDLE only when it is first created or right after it commits. Any transaction that holds or has held any resource in the database is ACTIVE. Accessing the TransactionTable virtual table without using the class alias will not activate the transaction.
If null, this is a read-only transaction. If not null, this is the first log record instant written by the transaction.
If null, this transaction is currently not being executed in the database. If not null, this is the SQL statement currently being executed in the database.
